segments.text: But the point I was going to make that I wanted to come back to was prior to 1980 and in the Institute for Solid State Electronics, on more than one occasion, I had been approached by industry or individuals starting a business to do work, to fund work, development work at Texas A&M in our Institute for Solid State Electronics.
And of course, I'd already
gotten several patents myself at Texas Instruments, and then again in the work Jack and I was doing together on the solar cell.

And the difference between the industrial world and the agricultural world, as my old friend Neville Clark used to say, who was director of the Aggie Transfer Station while I was the engineering, he said, you know, technology transfer
in the farming business is you pick up the phone and call your neighbor and tell him you've got a sack of the new hybrid corn out on the porch, come by and get a cup full.
And TI doesn't call up Motorola and tell them they've got a new circuit design, come by and make a copy.
And I had argued as a faculty member in the late 70s that we had to get an intellectual property policy.
And Fred Bitson
and said, we're a publicly funded institution, and whatever we do is owned by all the people, and we give it away.
And I said, hell, you can't give it away.
Nobody will take it.
Nobody's going to put the extra resources into it that have to be.
If it's public, that's right.
If they can't own it.
That's right.
You can't give it.
You can sell it to TI, but you cannot give it to them.
And I couldn't argue that point.
As a faculty member, I couldn't get enough attention.
But when I became the director of the Engineering Experiment Station, I was a member of the Executive Committee.
I ran a state agency.
I had resources.
And I couldn't argue the point at the Executive Committee level.
The board understood it implicitly and pushed for it.
And the chancellor formed a team to review and study it and put forth a recommendation, and we did.
In those days, I got to chair a lot of fun stuff.
I got to chair the research park committee, the airport committee.
It was an interesting period for me.
And the recommendation was to do it.
Texas A&M wouldn't put any money in it, and the Ag Experiment Station wouldn't put any money in it.
The system argued they didn't have any money, so I funded the whole thing myself.
Did you?
I did it.
Hired the first guy in the Experiment Station, and got a policy that we would split 50-50 with any researcher, whatever we got out of it.
And when we negotiated the first royalty for a million dollars,
out of the development in the Food Protein R&D Center, Ed Lucis' operation, when they came up with a technique for taking the soy taste out of soybean oil.
And we licensed that to a Japanese company for $1 million to be paid $100,000 a year over 10 years.
And I got the first $100,000 check and cut a $50,000 check to these three guys over in the Food Protein R&D Center.
It was interesting the stimulus that was for all the new patent applications.
And it was also interesting the impact that had within the system, because shortly thereafter it was decided that we needed to move this office over to the system.
It was done.
And I was pleased, but I never got paid back.
The university and the experience station all agreed they owed me money.
But to my knowledge, I put way over $150,000 of the Engineering Experiment Station's money on behalf of the A&M system with prorated parts to be paid by different system parts.
I don't know what's ever happened to that, but I know the history well because I did it.
And I had to do it.
I just had to do it.
But I knew it had to be done.
You know, to create a property right.
Sure.

If you're ever going to link, and the nation is going to get any opportunity for the academic and industrial community to learn how to work together, the academic community had to mature to the point of being able to say, yes, we own this property, yes, we can license it to you, and yes, we will work with you to make money off of it for yourself.
And that that'll
Pay some of the mothers and daddies in a job that you give them whose children are likely to come back to this institution.
And while that may not be uniformly equal, if we tried the other way, as Fred used to argue about a lot of other things, we'd reach uniform mediocrity.
So at any rate, I go back to that point because it's relevant to the Hark story.
And we can come to that in a minute, but I'll try to focus on that.

And the relevancy and the importance and the difference between HARC and, say, the Texas A&M System or the Engineering Experiment Station as an agency of the state operating in the A&M System, trying to effectively link the private sector with the academic sector
is the bureaucracy and constraint of a publicly funded institution over a private one, which is New York.

And when you look around the country, and I began to do that, as I began to think how, OK, I've got this responsibility as a CEO of a state agency to turn this agency into an effective way to help the state of Texas support its industry.
like the agricultural experiment station, has helped its farmers.
I'm supposed to be helping the TIs and the...
But you have a whole different constituency out there.
Oh, and a very different philosophy.

And if you try other than the generic one to say the engineering experiment station should be helping industry as the agricultural experiment station helped the agribusiness industry, or the farmers more specifically, the analogy breaks down.
Very fast.
And when you look around the country, as I was going to say, and you look at Silicon Valley and Menlo Park, you find Stanford and SRI.
And Stanford's private, and SRI's private.
Stanford Research Institute are now SRI International.
But it's kind of the link.
to do research of relevance to industry that drew on the talent at Stanford, which was SRI.
But industry went to SRI, not to Stanford.
And when you look at Route 128 in the Boston miracle, you find Harvard and MIT private.
When you go to the Research Triangle Park, you find Duke and the Research Triangle Institute

private now you find North Carolina North Carolina State which are public and also a member of the Research Triangle Institute but this theme of private institutions is too consistent to ignore particularly when you're running an agency in the state like Texas dealing with the Bubba's in Austin so you had to come keenly aware of this
Yeah, the difference.
Character.
That's right.
And I had become keenly aware.
I had been forced to become keenly aware, asking myself, can it be this tough for all these other areas that are doing it, that I've got all of this politics to fight through?
And why do I have all of this politics?
Well, I had all of this politics to fight through because this state, Achilles' heel of our education, is you buy your seat.
on a board of higher education.
It's who gives the governor, the winning governor, the most money.
And the greatest prize or seats on UT Austin and Texas A&M, those are the two most coveted ones.
And we occasionally get very talented members.
But that's an accident, not a cause.
And see, I've gone beyond the knee-jerk fear of even putting this on tape, Henry.
This is so important to the state's future that it needs to be said.
The fact that when I started reporting to Texas A&M Board of Regents, one of them had an eighth-grade education and really got my attention.

And I wondered, wonderful guy, good old rancher from Uvalde, but hell, he was a big old hunting and fishing buddy with Dolph Briscoe, and he just gave old Dolph a lot of money and got him elected, and Dolph
Asking what he wanted, he told him, and hell, he gave it to him.
He didn't have any business being on Texas A&M before.
I mean, he loved us a lot, and he showed up to meetings, and he was a wonderful guy.
But how can you be on the board of anything if you don't understand their product?
I mean, it's a travesty.
So we've got some excellent board members in this state on our boards.
But I handpicked the one at ARC.
I didn't check with the governor.
And it didn't have anything to do with who they were for or against.
It had to do with who they are, what they know, and what they produced.
It's a very different approach and much more relevant, I think, to building the kind of institution that can serve.
And I think that that's probably the single most distinguishing thing between
A private university or institution and a public one is the way the board selected.
Next, and maybe of equal importance, is the public perception of the use of public funds.
Tax dollars.
It's different to go out for Rice University to go out and ask for money to run the institution.
and have people give it to you than it is just to tax the citizens and then allocate it to the public institution.
There's a different level of accountability that's implied in that.
I think that's one of the reasons that an institution like Texas A&M for so long, even in defiance of logic, it's such a powerful thing.
It's kind of like Galileo had the telescope for six months before he even thought about looking at the heavens with it.
It was the province of the church.
I mean, he was using it as a navigational tool.
And then one day he looked up and saw a star and said, gee, this is exciting.
So there's a built-in inflexibility.
Yeah, there's a built-in perceptional thing that you can't go through that barrier.
I mean, that's everybody.
So whatever you develop here, you give it to everybody when you can't.
But you still keep thinking that you ought to be able to do that somehow when it's impossible.
That's not the culture of the grand process.
So all of that was beginning to sink in in my experience base of being challenged to run a state agency that was challenged to provide this link.
And my own experience as a professor and my own experience as an industrialist and my growing experience as an industrialist, as a member of the board of a high technology company, as a member
of the research staff of a major corporation like Texas Instruments.
So, PARC was created in 1983, roughly, on paper.
Where?
Who?
That was done on the initiative of George Mitchell.
And George Mitchell contacts who?
Okay.
Or did someone contact George Mitchell?
No, I think this was George's own self-initiative.
And George has launched the real estate development of the Woodlands, which I believe was done about 15 years ago now, maybe 16.
So George launched the Woodlands in 69, 71, whatever.
And most of what I'll say now is my impressions of what was happening as opposed to specific historical documentation.
This is kind of images.
based upon untold hours of George and I talking and hearing one another talk.
You know, I think if we were doing this parallel kind of path, what I've just told you about my own experience, if we backed up
In the 70s and tried to ask the question, now what's George learning out there?
And where is he going?
And how did what he was doing and what I was doing cause these curves to cross?
It's kind of the way I see this.
Because when Matt and George's curves crossed, vis-a-vis Hark at least, now we crossed to know one another prior to Hark.
And that was because George was an Aggie.
or is an Aggie, and he was asked to chair the Target 2000 project.
That's where you first encountered Mitchell?
That's right.
And Target 2000 was A&M's effort to follow the governor, then Governor Clements' lead in Texas 2000, which had been a state study on the future of Texas.
And so following that, A&M launched Target 2000.

all of the issues that i've just reviewed with you from my personal perspective of what was going on with skip porter back in those days uh you know that's just one one man's view and uh you could get this from several people that were watching what i was doing who would tell you a completely antithetical story of what i've just said because what they were seeing me do had no resemblance at all to what i just told you i was doing well no i think i am aware of both
Several images.
Yeah, yeah.
But yours is the first time I've heard that statement.
Yeah.
And because what, in my judgment, and by my firsthand measure, by the fall of 1984, the success or failure of what I had turned the Texas Engineering Experiment Station
into, depending upon who you talk to.
I mean, in my judgment, I had done what I had been asked to do by the board and the chancellor, at least initially.
As those people changed, particularly the chancellor and not so much the board, but I think they, at that point in time, had maybe wished I hadn't been asked to do what I was doing.
There was one little point I was going to try to make in there that escaped me now.
We were talking about TARC 2000.
all of this different perception of what in the hell is going on with this A&M system.
I mean, gee, should we move all these agencies back over under the university?
Gee, should we have one guru dude that could somehow keep all of this patched together in some magical way?
And we went through vice president of agriculture and vice president of engineering for a while.
Then we went to Deputy Chancellor of Agriculture and Deputy Chancellor of Engineering, and then we went...
I mean, we were trying Management 101 every other month up there.
It was a joke.
It was really boring to be in that, to have responsibility when... outside of all of that concern... You know, it was a neat, clean world.
Oh, God.
It was so...
I mean, we fumbled the ball...
Texas A&M could have captured the intellectual leadership in the state of Texas in five years in 1980.
It made two, which I'm not going to talk about, bad calls back to back.
It killed it.
And it was hard to overcome that.
I don't think it has yet.
And subsequently.
one to that I've quit watching it because it's too painful.
It's amazing the resiliency of an institution that continues to do unusually amazingly well.
It's hard to kill a good place.
It is a good place.
But it's always sad to be close when you knew it could have been so much better.
But anyway, that was part of it.
But this was really a tumultuous time.
I don't know, you'd have to ask George
his perception of what he learned about the institution and the players, being head of the entire Target 2000 project.
Had he at that time now become aware of the operations and the character of teams while he was on to Target 2000?
Oh, I think so.
I think he became aware during the Target 2000 study.
OK.
But HARC already, by 83 or whatever, exists?
Yeah, on paper it exists.
On paper?
Yeah.
It's a legal entity.
It does not do anything.
But it has actually been created as a legal entity?
Oh, yes.
Yes.
Has it worked?
Do you remember that?
No, I don't.
But it's around somewhere.
It may have even been as early as late 82 sometime.
But I think it was in 83.
So it's sitting here, then?
Oh, yeah.
It exists.
It's a created institution.
has bylaws, has a board, but has nobody to run it.
And I'm approached by Arthur D. Little, the consulting firm which George hired, to do a study of how other regions had evolved and developed in economic diversification.
And they studied them.
They studied the entry in
the Illinois Institute of Technology in the Illinois area, they studied Route 128, they studied Silicon Valley, they studied Research Triangle Park.
And I think George decided that the best model that he saw out of all of that for Houston and for Texas would be the Research Triangle Park.
And that if Houston could take the lead in pulling together- Do you know why he decided that?
No.
I don't know if it was the relative level of growth of unrelated industries.
I'm guessing now, absolutely guessing.
George and I never specifically talked about, I've heard him say that in
conversation to others several times.

So I know there's been a mix of the institution because the diverse Well, I think I think in the invitation of particularly initially, Rice was the Duke and UH and Texas A&M were the North Carolina North Carolina State, so to speak, of the Research Triangle Institute, but it may also have been George is pretty deep thinker.
He doesn't come to a decision casually or without insight.
One of the brightest guys I've ever met.
And he, it may well be, and I'm trying to ask myself that question now, trying to think of it as I'm sure George would analyze it at that time.
Texas is strong in energy, and North Carolina is strong in textiles.
Kind of one major horse driving, yet the strength,
of already existing spot-off industries may have also been similarly weak.
I don't know.
Maybe it was because they both had a lot of pound trees.
But at any rate, Arthur D. Little goes then to the institutions to inquire if they would be willing to participate.
Duke, North Carolina, and North Carolina State had done with RTI in the, in HARC, which was then called the Houston Area Research Center, now Houston Advanced Research Center.
And so I was interviewed.
And Little was coming to you, and then basically you had to invite participation.
Well, to get my opinion.
Oh, okay.

As a key person at Texas A&M, as to whether or not I think this makes sense or not, and several of us on Texas A&M's campus, as I'm sure on the other campuses were interviewed, what would you think about?
They had a neat little list of questions prepared that I was asking.
John Calhoun was asked, and others.
Meanwhile, about the same time now, Calhoun, I assume, and Winnarty are...
Doing the medical, beginning to get involved in the medical?
Well, Winarty's already down.
He's already down.
Yeah, well, or he's at, Winarty at that point in time is with Gulf.
Okay.
He's with Gulf Research.
Okay.
Calhoun is still at A&M, and he's the vice president for engineering, matter of fact.
Okay.
I'll lose track of who was in what position when, but for a while Calhoun took over from Fred Benson as the Vice President and Deputy Chancellor of Engineering.
But I'm asked to give recommendations to the A&M Board of Regents as to whether or not A&M ought to affiliate with PARCC.
And I can see some real potential benefit.
And I can see opportunities for conflict or competitive, even potentially negative competitive, if HAARC doesn't perceive its collaborative role to enhance and support.
But my final analysis is that because at that point in time, for example,
The engineering experiment station had responsibility for delivering all computing services to the A&M system.
Remember the data processing center was a part of TEAS?
Yeah.
And I was put in charge again of the computer committee to advise the system on what computer acquisitions for the future we should be making.
And the issue of should we have a supercomputer?
Should we have another central processor or should we have distributed computing?
I mean, I'd waded through that.
Old Mac Prescott was on the committee, and Neville Clark, and I forget who else.
But I got the black bean again to chair that baby.
As I say, I had a lot of interesting responsibilities during those times.
And, well, there was no way we could justify spending $10 million or so on a supercomputer.
There was no way any university in the state could justify doing that.
unless you just wanted to buy $10 million worth of image to say you had one.
There's nothing easier to share than a computer.
And anybody that's ever had to operate one knows you don't want to.
Let somebody else operate it.
You'd be a user.
And then you can complain why it doesn't work.
So one of the things I suggested straight away is that Hark should go after a supercomputer and network it into all the collaborative universities.
And the university should look to HARC and support HARC as the place for major, unusual computing resources to be provided to it.
And you're thinking this primarily as director of TEAS?
Yes.
And as being in charge, basically, of the future computer needs and so forth of the university?
You bet.
That's right.
And I'm thinking of it also.
When you say director of TEAS, remember, I've learned to look at that as a state agency.
And while it's located on Texas A&M's campus, well, it's an agency that serves the state, not just College Station.
And that's something I'm sure the university had very great difficulty.
Oh, big time.
I had more trouble with the Aggies than I had with anybody else on that point, because all of those resources of that agency of the state
They had been so long used to using them as they wanted to, particularly the College of Engineering.
Just the College of Engineering.
And with the College of Education and the College of Business and the College of Veterinary Medicine.
When we started opening up these other divisions, which globally expanded the research capability.
You're going to talk to Bill Mobley today about the value that was to you.
You'll hear it.
And that's where that college learned how to be competitive outside on the street with writing proposals.

That's when we created Invent, the Institute for Ventures in New Technology, which you go talk to the students in the MBA program at Texas A&M, was far more valuable and exciting to them than any course they ever took.
But that was not happily received.
It was a delusion.
I was spending, quote, Aggie money with the Longhorns or with the Lamar guys or with UT Arlington.
And it was just this little narratini view of all the world was centered in College Station.
It was hard to overcome.
It still is.
It's a big-time syndrome.
It's true on most campuses.
Yeah, it is.
It's true on most individual professors.
I mean, you don't really care what happens at all.
It's what's in your lab.
in your life, in your profession.

And so I think that's important to understand from my personal perspective, to the extent that that's interesting in the history of the Woodlands at heart, is that I was committed intuitively as an individual, and maybe unusually, from the time I came to Texas A&M.
I mean, when I came to Texas A&M in 68, I was in an unusual position at Texas Instruments.
I met every week with Fred Busey, the president of Texas Instruments, because the project that I was developing there was so important to Texas Instruments.
And when I left and was on Texas A&M's campus, I could pick up the phone any minute and call the president of TI and get through.
And I did it.
And I'd say, Fred, we're missing a bet here.
God, Texas A&M needs TI, and TI needs Texas A&M, and I see how to put this thing together.
He said, okay, get on back down here.
And he taught all the VPs together, and I'd go to Dallas, and everybody would agree it's wonderful, and I'd walk out of there, and everybody else would go back to doing what they had to get done.
It's hard to make this work.
This is not easy.
But T's got started on that, but it created enough of a local whirlwind
that it really made it just, I mean, life's too short.
So I was kind of getting to that point where, you know, I had kind of two choices on a personal level.
I could either toe off and win or real bloody win.
And I was real confident that that's the way to work out.
Or I could just say, hey, you've got too much respect for the institution and all of what could happen.
And there's too much opportunity in your life of positivism.
Sure.
Why do all this negative stuff and end up doing damage to what you've loved and worked for?
Just walk away and let everybody else take off with it and see what happens.
Maybe they're right and you're wrong.
Just go do your other thing.
So that's kind of where I finally came out.
OK.
So the concept is here.
Little has approached you.
You've approached the board.
suggesting involvement, participation.
Yes, I supported the idea long before I met George Mitchell.
I didn't know who he was.
That's good.
But it was easy for me to do that because that was philosophically the plane I was trying to get A&M on and learn more about myself.
This was a risk I believed as a nation we had to be taking.

I could feel this from just intuitively out on the street in Oregon and in Dallas and in College Station and in New York City and wherever else it was, I was going professionally and I was seeing the number of Japanese people showing up and presenting electronics papers.
I just knew we had to start doing some things differently and take the risk of doing that.
And I believed intuitively of the value of winking.
I call them the three separate societies in our single one, government, industry, and academia.
They just don't talk to one another, and they don't understand the culture, and their cultures are very different.
NASA has the same problem.
Well, they're part of the government.
That's right.
Yeah.
And they're trying to establish those same linkages.
Yes, right.
And this institution can help much better than a publicly funded research university.
And it will, and it is.
And I hope it will.
That's my goal.
So, go ahead.
At what point now were you approached to come to HAARP?
Okay.
Well, in 1980, late 83 or early 84, probably late 83.
Well, HAARP was born in 83, let's say.
And John Calhoun served on the executive committee
of HARC's board of directors as the A&M representative.
Each of the founding universities had four members on HARC's board, and one of those members served on the executive committee, which George Mitchell chaired.
But that was all that ever happened, to my knowledge.
the executive committee would meet.
I don't think the full board ever did.
And the executive committee would just kind of get and say, well, what do you guys think we could do to get HARC started?
What would be a good project?
Well, I'm not sure of the transition.
We'd have to go back to the records to find this.
But it was after Frank Vandiver had become president of Texas A&M and after John Calhoun retired, Frank called me and asked me
to represent Texas A&M on Hark's board and be on the executive committee.
Because Hark's bylaws call for the presidents of those universities to appoint those people.
And that's when I met George Mitchell.
Where exactly the target 2000 study is at that point in time, and where and how George and I may have or may not have interacted back on Texas A&M's campus, I don't know exactly.
But I came to know George consciously that he was a Texas A&M graduate, that he was a guy living in Houston, and he was in the oil and gas business.
And that when he was asked,
to chair the Target 2000.
That's how I met him.
I went to one of our organizational meetings and I met George Mitchell.
I had no idea that he was the forces behind HARC or that he had a real estate project called the Woodlands or anything else.
And how, what he learned about me during that process and who I was and what the engineering experimentation was doing and anything else, I have no idea.
Vandiver appointed you to the board as a representative of Texas A&M.
I might argue you wouldn't slight lead if we picked up this morning.
In fact, Vandiver apparently had some pretty close association with Roger Gallagher's Gladys.
That could have been part of it.
Could be, yeah.
Well, I don't think so, because Roger's joined this company since I've been here.
Part of that, he was with Exxon and Prince.
He said he joined in 79.
Did he?
Yeah.
Ah, okay.
Well, he's become president since I've been here.
He became president in 86.
Yeah, okay.
I know he became president since I've been here, but he's with the company.
Okay.
Yeah, that's interesting, yeah.
Well, okay.
So I start coming on A&M's behalf,
to the executive committee of the HART board.
So Frank has really asked me to represent Texas A&M in an official capacity.
I guess with my professorial hat of double E on.
I think it's in a way that's an odd, where you're the director of TEAS, a state agency.
Yeah, but I was also a professor of engineering.
But that, again, is the kind of murky lines of, plus Frank and I knew one another well.
Of course, we served on the system executive committee together.
And there's nothing that any one of those entities does that doesn't have some relationship and impact on the other.
And so I was pleased to do that.
Told Frank I'd be happy to do it.
I really didn't know what it involved or entailed.
I knew about HARC because I had been inquired and interviewed by Arthur Little.
So I put forth the idea of the supercomputer at a board meeting.
George had brought in

or I guess the executive committee of the board had concurred to hire a guy named Harvey McMains, who worked with George Kosmetsky at the Institute for Constructive Capitalism, IC Squared, at UT Austin.
And Harvey came here on, I think, a halftime basis to be the interim president of HARC.
And so Harvey would sit in on these meetings.
So a team was organized, pulling together some of the professors from various institutions.
I think the lead came out of the University of Houston to go after one of the NSF centers for supercomputing.
And that proposal was written and submitted in 84.
Also, in late...
Excuse me, that's an NSF application.
Did you say NSF?
Yes, National Science Foundation.
And it basically is sort of a cooperative application between universities centered through Hartz and Minsky applications.
That's right.
And these are members of a collegial or whatever association.
That's right, yeah.
So the proposal...
NSF had announced they were going to establish four national supercomputer centers.
And so our proposal was that one of those be here at HARC, which would link the collaborative institutions and serve all these different research universities.
And I'll come back to that in a second, if you like.
But we ranked in the top eight.

four there were eight picked as finalists and then four of those eight were funded and we were not one of those and so when i came here in january of 1985 as hark's first full-time president or first president i guess i should say one of my first moves was to go to nsf and find out why we didn't win
and to see what it would take in order to come after such a designation in the future, and learned that that was not likely to happen.
There were not going to be those resources.
And so we went after bringing the supercomputer in here on our own initiative, working with the private sector.
And we're successful at doing it, as you know.
Why didn't Art get that?
the first initiative?
What'd you find out?
I really have to go back and review that.
It's been too long since I've asked the question.
Technical, mechanical, philosophical?
Well, it wasn't so glaring that I remember it six years later.
It was competition, and
We were complimented.
We had a good proposal, a competitive proposal.
We just got beat.
You can get beat for a lot of reasons.
That follows into a lot of interesting stuff that will be interesting in the history of the park, I think, but not so much the history of the woodlands.
But also, I still haven't gotten you here yet.
You're in 1980, but who hired you?
The board of Hark.
Who made that contact, direct contact?
George Mitchell.
And I'll tell you the details of that, but I want to get this other thought in while I've got it.
In 83, while I'm still the director of the engineering experiment station, the idea for the superconducting supercollider surfaces, the SSC,
And it surfaces on A&M's campus in a guy named Peter McIntyre.
And Peter goes to see Frank Vandiver, president of Texas A&M, and describes this mystical, magical, giant federal project.
And Frank says, Peter, that sounds exciting, but that's a big deal.
Go see Porter.
So he comes to see me.
And I listened.
And McIntyre's kind of a guy that you can't not listen to.
And I listened long enough to gain enough insight to realize that this project was of a scope and a dimension that it was unlikely the state of Texas could play.
The whole state.
It was certainly impossible for Texas A&M, the entire system, certainly not Texas A&M University, but if we pulled everything the A&M system had, we weren't even close.
I mean, we weren't even close.
And the thought of Hark hit me.
If the state of Texas wanted to line up and try to compete in that league,

in the intellectual business of big science, Park was the only chance it had that it would take pooling the best minds of our four largest research institutions with the structure of a new institution designed to do this kind of thing.
So at a sequence of events, I told Peter he ought to go meet George Mitchell.
who was chairman of the board of a new institution called HARC.
And this began to get enough visibility on A&M campus that it began to make a lot of people nervous.
Art Hanson was getting nervous.
Perry Atkinson was getting nervous.
Frank Vandiver was getting nervous.
And we were spending a lot of time at the executive committee level of the system talking about this project.
Did McIntyre go to see Mitchell?
Yes, he did.

And he took Sheldon Glashow with him, the Nobel laureate from Harvard, with a lot of preposterous proposals, thinking it would apply to the flamboyant, big scope nature of Texas and big oil, talking about
the Texatron, and they'd use this to find all bio-absorbent neutrinos in the earth and a bunch of stuff like that, which George, of course, saw through.
But intellectually, the project was interesting.
I finally became convinced that Peter McIntyre had enough energy and interest and commitment to this
that it might be possible that they could pull a team together.
So I brought the idea as the executive committee member of HARC's board representing Texas A&M.
I committed A&M in toto that if HARC wanted to run with this, we'd back their play.
That got it off of our campus, got us out of the lead hot seat, which everybody was big time nervous about, and put it

in an institution that had some chance of leading and pulling together all the other talent that would have to come from Bryce and UT Austin and U of H, plus all that would have to be hired and have some entity that could nurture and manage it to get us competitive.
And George liked that.
It was the second project.
So we had the second.
